source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: The matrix composition in one Zircaloy-2 (Zry-2) and four Zircaloy-4 (Zry-4) materials has been measured with the atom probe technique.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: The matrix composition in one Zircaloy-2 (Zry-2) and four Zircaloy-4 (Zry-4) materials has been measured with the atom probe technique.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: It was found that only about 10% of the alloying elements Fe, Cr, and Ni added to the alloy remain in solid solution in the matrix of nuclear fuel claddings.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: No significant difference in matrix concentration of Fe and Cr could be detected in Zry-4 materials with different heat treatment and different corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Even a Zry-4 material analyzed directly after a β quench operation had a matrix concentration of only 0.02 wt% Fe and 0.03 wt% Cr.

evidence_span: Even a Zry-4 material analyzed directly after a β quench operation had a matrix concentration of only 0.02 wt% Fe and 0.03 wt% Cr.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Atom probe analysis was also used to study the oxide-metal interface in oxide layers formed in dry air and water on needle shaped Zry-4 specimens.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Transmission electron microscopy of the oxide layers showed that these were approximately 10 nm thick and contained 5 nm sized oxide crystallites in an amorphous layer.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Transmission electron microscopy of the oxide layers showed that these were approximately 10 nm thick and contained 5 nm sized oxide crystallites in an amorphous layer.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: According to atom probe analysis, the thin oxide layers had a low oxygen content, less than 50 atomic percent.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Small changes in the alloy chemistry, such as higher Si and Fe additions and a lower Sn concentration, have proven favorable for the corrosion properties of the materials [2].

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: Charquet et al. [10] have thoroughly examined the separate and combined solubility of Fe and Cr in the α-phase of alloys resembling the Zircaloys. They found that the highest combined solubility of Fe + Cr was 150 weight ppm at 810°C in a Zry-1.4Sn alloy with a Fe-to-Cr ratio similar to that in Zry-4.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk1
evidence_span: In these measurements, the lowest value registered corresponded to a matrix that had reached its equilibrium solute contents. This value was obtained in a formerly β-quenched material after only 1 min of annealing at 600°C.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: In the approximately 1-nm-thick oxide-metal interface the oxygen content decreased to less than 1 atomic percent.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The oxygen content remained at this level during the subsequent analysis of the metal. This is consistent with the bulk composition of the alloy, 0.7 atomic percent.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The atom probe analysis shows that the matrix is highly depleted of the alloying elements due to precipitation. Of the Fe and Cr added to the alloys, only about $10 \%$ remains in the matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: In this material, the small amounts of Fe and Cr detected are only slightly higher than the solubility limit in $\alpha - \mathsf { Z r }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The cooling rate used, $2 0 \%$ is not sufficient to give a supersaturated matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The thermoelectric power measurements by Gros and Wadier [6] gave observations of a high Fe $^ +$ Cr concentration that remained in the matrix up to $3 0 \ s$ after annealings at $6 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: Therefore the matrix of commercial materials should be less depleted at this stage of the production.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The additions of Si in material 5a are not large enough to be detected by atom probe analysis.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The small change in precipitate sizes due to Si [31] does not cause any measurable change of matrix concentration.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: If there are differences in the matrix composition between the materials studied, they should be less than $0 . 0 1 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: the low oxygen concentration measured in the thin oxide layers shows undoubtedly that the analyzed oxide layer was not entirely $\mathbf { Z r O } _ { 2 }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: Results from this work can be compared with atom probe analysis of anodic oxide, formed during electropolishing at room temperature [34]. The anodic oxide contained 54 atomic percent oxygen

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: TEM studies revealed 3 to $4 \mathrm { n m }$ crystallites in an approximately 6-nmthick oxide layer.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk4
evidence_span: The materials were one Zry-2 and two Zry-4 commercial materials, and two experimental Zry-4 materials, of which one was $\beta$ quenched and one had a low annealing parameter.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: with the $\beta$ -quenched samples having the highest resistivity.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: The resistivity tended to increase with a decrease in average precipitate size.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: EDX analyses showed that precipitates in oxide films dissolved into oxide matrix during the corrosion process in high temperature steam.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Very fine precipitates in $\beta$ -quenched Zry-2 would have disappeared early in the corrosion process.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: The improvement in corrosion resistance by $\beta$ -quenching was attributed not to short-circuit effects of precipitates but to a change in oxide properties induced by an increase in the amount of alloying elements retained in the matrix.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_030_chunk6
evidence_span: Zry-2 with a smaller average size and higher density of precipitates is more resistant to nodular corrosion than that having fewer but larger precipitates
